name: Egyptian Vulture
description: In adulthood, it is unmistakable. It has the least bald head and neck of all vultures and is the smallest among them. Its feathers are predominantly white, with dark flight feathers, and its bare skin on the head is yellow to orange. Young birds are brownish.
spread_note: Southern Europe in several subspecies, eastward to Central Asia and northwestern India, also northern Africa to Tanzania, Arabia. Some populations migrate to sub-Saharan Africa in winter.
food_note: Carrion, ostrich eggs, small vertebrates, occasionally overripe fruits
image_alt: Egyptian Vulture, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 36–44 cm, tail length 22–26 cm, wingspan 155–170 cm, weight 1.6–2.2 kg
attractions: Unlike other vultures, it has a relatively weak beak. It mainly collects food, so only its face is bare, while the rest of its head and neck are feathered. It’s a skilled flier—covering up to 80 km daily while searching for food. Its diet includes carrion as well as bird eggs, especially ostrich eggs, which it breaks open using a stone held in its beak.
breeding: The first Egyptian Vultures arrived in 1936. We bred them with a brief interruption in the 1940s until 1973, after which the species disappeared from the zoo for 20 years. Successful breeding resumed in 2000, and since then, we’ve raised 12 more chicks, including triplets in 2014.
